dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARGARET O'MALLEY, an auburn haired, sunburned 38-year ol mother of eight, stands outside next to the running stati wagon. Two children sit in the front seat while three are crammed into the back seat. Margaret is waiting on her two youngest boys to fill the way back seats that face backwards. KATIE, 4 years old, w strawberry blond hair, rosy cheeks, and a pot belly, stic her head out the window.

dialogues.speaker: KATIE
dialogues.text: Mom, I told them to be ready by nine twenty. They just don’t listen. Margaret ignores Katie. Katie pops back into the car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PETE, 7 years old, who looks like a poster boy for Irelan lays on his stomach in front of the board game "All Star Baseball". He spins the dial. The dial lands on nine, whi is the number that coincides with a strikeout. SEAMUS, ni years old, blondish brown hair, white skin, crystal blue eyes, angelic smile, jumps to the air in celebration.

dialogues.speaker: SEAMUS
dialogues.text: Another comeback stopped.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: Reggie Jackson stinks!

dialogues.speaker: SEAMUS
dialogues.text: We gotta get going. Mom's gonna freak. Seamus heads for the door.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: What should we tell her? Seamus looks back at Pete. Pete's hand me down plaid pant barely fit him and fall as he stands up.

dialogues.speaker: SEAMUS
dialogues.text: You couldn't find your belt. Seamus takes off down the stairs. Pete, with one hand hol up his pants, follows him down the stairs. Seamus runs ou the front door and past his mom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why are you late? Seamus, never breaking stride, climbs into the station wa through the back window.

dialogues.speaker: SEAMUS
dialogues.text: Pete couldn't find his belt. Pete runs past his mother.

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: Why are you late?

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: Seamus lost my belt. Pete never breaks stride. He jumps into the back of the station wagon. Margaret turns and walks to the car with t kind of steam that only eight kids in 18 years can produc She opens the car door, sits down, calmly puts the car in reverse, and turns her head for the reverse shoulder chec And then all hell breaks loose. Margaret screams at the t of her lungs.

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: God gives you 168 hours in a week. Can you not give him one full hour back? Is that too much to ask? Katie at four years doesn't understand rhetorical questio

dialogues.speaker: KATIE
dialogues.text: I've been ready for three hours. EDDIE, 14, brown curly hair, brown eyes, athletic, is at point in his life when he realizes he has more answers th his mom.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: (to Katie) Shut up you kiss ass. Margaret, with no hesitation, stops the car and smacks Ed across the face. Eddie winces while TOMMY, 17, also dark haired and dark eyed, laughs. Margaret puts the car in dr and cruises down the street like one big, happy family. W FOLLOW the camera through the front of the car to the bac PATRICK, 18, blondish brown curly hair and green eyes, ho MOLLY, six months old, in the front seat. Car seats have to be invented. MARY, 17, auburn haired like her mother and Tommy's twin, sits behind the driver seat because she has learned the l hand of Margaret's wrath cannot reach her in that seat. T reads Eddie the Bazooka Joe joke from his gum wrapper and the two laugh. In the back seat facing out, Pete and Seam sit. Seamus holds electronic football in his hand and the electronic sound of electronic football players running reverberates throughout the car. WE GO TIGHT on PETE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My dad is a fireman. WE PULL BACK and see all of the kids hang out the window wave at JOE, 40, who is Dark Irish, handsomely weathered, and happy to be at work when his wife takes the kids to church. WE GO TIGHT on JOE as he waves back to the kids.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: (sarcastic to fellow firemen) I wish I could be with them more.

dialogues.speaker: PETE, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: And my mom? WE GO TIGHT on MARGARET.

dialogues.speaker: PETE, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: And my mom? She's a part time cook, maid, and nurse. But her full time job? She's a front line sergeant in God's army. Pete screams as Seamus scores another touchdown on electr football.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: Goddammit, would you two shut up with that game! Katie puts her hand over her mouth with the sound of the swearword. Tommy prepares for battle by holding back his laughter. Margaret erupts.

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: The lord's name in vain? Son of a bitch. At forty miles an hour in front of the firehouse Margaret lunges her open fist into the backseat and starts swingin like a tornado. Kids scurry, hoping to avoid the path of the tornado. The wagon swerves into the other lane. Joe and his buddies wa from their lounge chairs outside the firehouse. He takes swig from a plastic cup.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Dying in a fire sometimes doesn't sound so bad. The station wagon pulls up to church and the children jum out like clowns from a small car. Margaret drives off as children exit the station wagon. Patrick lifts Katie up t the basin of holy water. Katie splashes water on her forehead and makes a sign of cross. Patrick, annoyed, puts her down and points his finger at her. He gently touches the water with his index and midd finger and slowly makes the sign of the cross. Katie shak her head in agreement. Seamus dips his hand in the water and fake sneezes on Pet Pete punches him in the shoulder. Margaret walks in and proceeds to lead her ducklings down the aisle as the head in church turn to watch. Each kid genuflects, some better than others, and sit. Pe sits between Seamus and Patrick. He looks at Margaret. Sh smiles and winks at him. Pete looks up to the life-size J hanging high behind the altar. WE SLOWLY go TIGHT on JESU hanging on the cross.

dialogues.speaker: PETE, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: My cousins' families are similar to mine. Except some of the dads are cops. In my world, there's Irish Catholics, and then there's everybody else. The only part of this picture that doesn't fit for me is Jesus. From what I've learned, and according to my brother Seamus I've learned shit, that's why I'm in second grade, but from what I've learned, Jesus is not Irish Catholic. My dad says that's only a technicality, like Knute Rockne, but, still, Jesus is not Irish Catholic. He is Jewish. I don't know any Jewish people, they don't go to Holy Cross, but if I ever meet a Jewish person, my mom says my job would be to convert them to Catholicism. So they could go to heaven. I have decided this summer, the summer of 1976, I will help a Jewish person get to heaven. It will be my holy quest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: REVERSE CAM - Looking out through Jesus's eyes. A WAKE. A Irish wake. Two little boys approach the casket. They kne in front of the casket. Seamus looks at Pete. Pete's eyes are wide in anticipation. Seamus nudges Pete. Pete nudges Seamus back. Seamus makes the sign of the cross and Pete copies him. The two stand and walk away. WE FOLLOW them through the crowd. The boys continue to walk through the crowd but WE STOP at a circle of men holding drinks. JOE, holding a Rum and Coke, is talking out the side of h mouth.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: So? What do I do? Go up to Aunt Maggie. Hey Aunt Maggie, did I mention Uncle Jim owed me a nickel? The other men laugh. Joe's fat brother, ROGER, answers as he's Jim's wife. He pulls out a coin

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know things are tight, Joe, but this is cheap. Even for you. Roger hands Joe the nickel.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Well, we'll call it even. That idiot. You know if he was up a nickel with the book, he would have lived to collect. The men laugh heartily.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: A new way to fend off death. Be up money with your bookie.

dialogues.speaker: ROGER
dialogues.text: May old Uncle Jim be in heaven thirty minutes before the devil knows he's dead.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: He might need more time. What if the devil has extradition rights? All of the men laugh. A man hands Joe a drink. He finishe the drink in his right hand as he accepts the fresh drink his left hand. Seamus and Pete come running back through the crowd. Marg standing with four women and smoking, calls them over.

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: Did you pray for your great uncle's soul? Pete looks at Seamus. Seamus looks down at Pete. Pete loo up at his mom.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: We didn't know his soul. The women laugh.

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: Cause he didn't have one.

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: Go back up there and pray to Jesus for the soul of your Uncle Jim. He needs your prayers.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: So I've heard. But Mom, how do we know our prayers will help Old Uncle Jim get to heaven?

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: Faith. Now go ahead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mom, we can't go back up there. We already prayed to Jesus for his soul. Mom looks at Pete for affirmation. Pete looks up to Seamu He looks back up to Mom.

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: Did you pray to Jesus? Pete looks at Seamus. Seamus gives him that scared look o having to look at that dead body up close again. Pete loo at the dead body. He looks back at his mom. He nods his head in the affirma

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: Well, nobody can have too many prayers. Go again. Pete and Seamus head toward the casket.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: How did she know I was lying?

dialogues.speaker: SEAMUS
dialogues.text: You weren't convincing. And she's got some kinda built in lie detector.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: How many lies do we get till we go to hell?

dialogues.speaker: SEAMUS
dialogues.text: Forty-seven.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: I don't think I have many left. And I got my whole life ahead of me.

dialogues.speaker: SEAMUS
dialogues.text: That one doesn't count. You just nodded. Nodding up and down in China is like saying no.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: Things are upside down in China. Seamus begins to nod yes but changes it to a shake. Marga watches the boys as they approach the casket. The boys approach the dead body.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: What's faith? Seamus's eyes are bugging out.

dialogues.speaker: SEAMUS
dialogues.text: A word grown ups use when they don't have the answer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WE GO TIGHT on an ELECTRONIC FOOTBALL GAME. WE HEAR the n of the game. WE PULL BACK to see Pete playing the game in the back of the room. A nun stands at the front of the cl and is talking to the class.

dialogues.speaker: NUN
dialogues.text: This summer, take time to reflect on your past year in the second grade. And how you can make third grade better. The electronic defense tackles Pete and makes a double cl noise.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: No!

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: Yes!

dialogues.speaker: NUN
dialogues.text: Mr. O'Malley? Do you disagree with me?

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: No, Sister Leonora Mary. I agree. The bell rings. The kids scream with happiness. School's for the summer.

dialogues.speaker: NUN
dialogues.text: See you at church. And next year in third grade. The boys run for the door.

dialogues.speaker: NUN
dialogues.text: Mr. O'Malley, may I speak to you for a moment? The boys stop. Pete looks at them. The guys don't hesitat They run out of the room. Sister Leonora Mary and Pete ar alone.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: Yes, Sister Leonora Mary.

dialogues.speaker: NUN
dialogues.text: How many times did I have to pull you by your ears to the front of the class and give you the ruler? Pete looks around for the answer.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: A lot!

dialogues.speaker: NUN
dialogues.text: Probably too many times, don't you think?  Pete nods.

dialogues.speaker: NUN
dialogues.text: I don't enjoy having to do that, you know. Pete looks at the ground and scratches the back of his ne

dialogues.speaker: NUN
dialogues.text: I think this is an important summer for you. This is the summer that you can choose to keep following the devil's way, or create a new path toward Jesus. Which path do you want to take?

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: The Jesus path.

dialogues.speaker: NUN
dialogues.text: Good. I expect to see a difference in you next year.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: You will, Sister Leonora Mary. I've got a plan. A quest!

dialogues.speaker: NUN
dialogues.text: Good! You may go. Enjoy your summer, I know you will.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: You too Sister Leonora Mary. Pete heads toward the door. He turns around.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: Do you know where I can find a synagogue?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pete stops his bike outside the synagogue. He looks to th top to see if there is a cross. No cross. A small family walks out of the synagogue. The men wear yarmukles. Pete stares at the yarmukles. He walks his bike to the door. H tries to open the door and maneuver the bike through the door. He is unsuccessful. A bearded, tiny gray man with glasses opens the door. Rabbi Kenny Jacobsen smiles at th young leprechaun.

dialogues.speaker: RABBI
dialogues.text: May I help you, son of Saint Patrick? Pete looks at him weird but shrugs off the name calling. notices the rabbi wears a yarmukle also.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: Whadaya got on the top of your head?

dialogues.speaker: RABBI
dialogues.text: The rabbi It's a yarmukle.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: Doesn't really block the sun.

dialogues.speaker: RABBI
dialogues.text: No but it covers bald spots. leans over, takes off the yarmukle, and shows Pete his bald spot.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: It does cover the bald spot. My old Uncle Jim could have used that.

dialogues.speaker: RABBI
dialogues.text: So what can I do you for? Pete looks around. The rabbi

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: Jewish people go here? nods.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: I'm looking to see if I can help Jewish people get to heaven.

dialogues.speaker: RABBI
dialogues.text: A noble endeavor.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: A quest!

dialogues.speaker: RABBI
dialogues.text: A noble quest! What can I do to assist your quest?

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: Well, I just wanted to check out the synagogue. But there's no bike rack. Don't kids go here?

dialogues.speaker: RABBI
dialogues.text: Yes. But not for school. How ‘bout I hold onto your bike in the back of the Temple as you look around?

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: Thanks. Pete enters the temple with Rabbi Jacobsen following him with the bike. The place is round and expansive. Pete loo around. After looking, Pete heads to the back of the temp where the rabbi waits for him with his bike.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: No cross?

dialogues.speaker: RABBI
dialogues.text: No cross.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I find the cross fun to look at. Sometimes I think about climbing the wall at Holy Cross and unscrewing the nails, and letting him go. Makes mass go faster. You should think about putting in a cross.

dialogues.speaker: RABBI
dialogues.text: I'll look into that. So what are you thinking?

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: That this is where the quest starts.

dialogues.speaker: RABBI
dialogues.text: Well, if I can be of service, you let me know. My office is just over there. I've got to get home to my family. I have a boy around your age. How old are you?

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: Seven. Almost eight.

dialogues.speaker: RABBI
dialogues.text: He's six. Almost seven.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: You can have a family?

dialogues.speaker: RABBI
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: Then what do they call you?

dialogues.speaker: RABBI
dialogues.text: Well, my boys call me father. But my congregation calls me Rabbi. Rabbi Jacobsen. Rabbi Jacobsen puts his hand out. Pete shakes it.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: I'm Pete. Pete O'Malley. Nice to meet you Rabbi Jacobsen.

dialogues.speaker: RABBI
dialogues.text: Nice to meet you. The rabbi and Pete head out of the temple.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The O'Malley's sit at the dinner table. Three things are constant at the dinner table. Meat, potatoes, and chaos. Katie starts to yelp.

dialogues.speaker: KATIE
dialogues.text: Can I have your attention? Please. I  got something to say. Please! Everyone at the table slowly quiets down.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Better make this good Katie.

dialogues.speaker: KATIE
dialogues.text: I will. The room is quiet. Katie looks at everyone.

dialogues.speaker: KATIE
dialogues.text: Today. I was on my bike. And I pedaled my bike to the O'Connors. And I pedaled back. And it was sunny. Everyone stares at her.

dialogues.speaker: KATIE
dialogues.text: That's it. Eddie shakes his head in amazement and grins.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: Katie, you need to come up with a more exciting story.

dialogues.speaker: KATIE
dialogues.text: I will.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: You know, like maybe crash your bike, and get really bloody and do the wounded soldier back to the house.

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: Eddie! The older kids laugh.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: Anyone know what a yarmukle is?

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: A beanie? Patrick looks at Pete.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: Jewish people wear them. It's traditional headwear.

dialogues.speaker: SEAMUS
dialogues.text: Like feathers for an Indian?

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: What's it for?

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: To hide their horns. The older kids laugh. Margaret winces.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They got horns?

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: No. They do not have horns. Joe, please. The young ones don't need this. Let's change the subject.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Patrick, your Uncle Charlie says he could get you an interview over at the city planners office.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: No thanks.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: What about the fire department?

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: That's always there. Well, kid, what the hell are you going to do? The kids react to the word hell.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: I've applied for some scholarships. I should hear about them soon. Until then, I can keep life guarding. Saving money .

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Life guarding? I've raised a professional lifeguarder. In Chicago. Work three months a year.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: And he doesn't even look like Sheila Moran in his suit. Tommy blushes.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: Sheila! Oh Sheila. Save me! Joe laughs.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Don't let her old man catch her saving you.

dialogues.speaker: TOMMY
dialogues.text: Eddie doesn't know what he's talking about. I don't like her. Mary speaks matter of factly.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Francis Demos told me Sheila likes you so all you need to do is ask her out.  Patrick gets up from the table as Tommy, Mary, and Eddie continue to talk about Sheila Moran. Seamus is bent over showing Pete where the horns protrude from the head. Kati feeds the cocker spaniel her mashed potatoes under the ta while Molly drinks from the bottle in Nancy's arms. Joe watches Patrick walk out of the room. He looks at Margare for some answer. Margaret shrugs her shoulders.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pete and Seamus walk down the tree lined city block in th neighborhood. The two sip milkshakes.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: There's nothing better than a bubble gum milk shake. How come that girl looks at us so funny when we order it? Seamus shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: I mean, it's a two for one. Ice cream shake, and then the bubble gum sinks to the bottom, and when the shake's done, you got a whole pack of bubble gum to chew. All for the price of one shake. Seamus takes the lid off the cup and tries to finish the shake in one big gulp. He succeeds. Seamus now chews on a wad of gum. Pete and Seamus pass a lemonade stand. Ten cents a cup. Pete motions to the lemonade entrepreneu that his shake has bankrupt him for the day.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: You ever feel that there's more out there? Like there's more for you to do than just play ball and eat ice cream? Seamus shakes his head. He blows a bubble. Pete blows a bubble.

dialogues.speaker: SEAMUS
dialogues.text: You gonna play baseball at 11? Pete shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: SEAMUS
dialogues.text: You heading over to the synagogue? Pete nods. Seamus blows a bubble.

dialogues.speaker: SEAMUS
dialogues.text: You know, this whole thing's kinda weird. You going there, the quest. Pete nods.

dialogues.speaker: SEAMUS
dialogues.text: Well, at least you know it's weird. Pete and Seamus walk down the street in silence. Enjoyin another day without responsibility.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pete knocks on the door of Rabbi Jacobsen's office.

dialogues.speaker: RABBI
dialogues.text: Come in.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: Hey Rabbi Jacobsen, Pete O'Malley. We met the other day. The rabbi stands up from his desk. He puts his hand out. Pete shakes it.

dialogues.speaker: RABBI
dialogues.text: Mr. O'Malley. How are you today?

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: I'm good thanks. Ready to start my quest. But I thought I might ask you for your permission first.

dialogues.speaker: RABBI
dialogues.text: What are your plans?

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: Sort of a "lemonade-free trip to heaven" stand. The rabbi chuckles. He stops.

dialogues.speaker: RABBI
dialogues.text: Enterprising. Pete shrugs off that word.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: Yep. Jewish people gotta like lemonade?

dialogues.speaker: RABBI
dialogues.text: Very much so. I believe Moses set one up at Mount Sinai. Again Pete shrugs off that statement.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: I figured I might set up the stand right at the door. And I'm not going to charge.

dialogues.speaker: RABBI
dialogues.text: A future car salesman.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: Right. OK then. Thanks. I'll let you know how it goes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, Jewish people believe in heaven. It's just that we believe it's not open yet.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: Well, maybe I can get the people that don't want to wait. The rabbi laughs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The rabbi walks back to the door. He turns back to look a Pete taping the poster to the wall. FREE LEMONADE. FREE T TO HEAVEN. The rabbi laughs. He opens the door and heads into the synagogue. Pete takes a seat at his stand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The rabbi watches Pete through a window in the synagogue. Pete looks around. No business. He looks around again. He pours himself a cup of lemonade and gulps it. He puts the lemonade back in its place.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The rabbi walks out to the stand. Pete looks dejected.

dialogues.speaker: RABBI
dialogues.text: Rome wasn't built in a day, Pete. Pete doesn't understand.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: How do you make any money here? I'm free, and still nobody. The rabbi pats Pete on the top of the head.

dialogues.speaker: RABBI
dialogues.text: I envy your youth. Come back tomorrow. Pete looks at all of his stuff.

dialogues.speaker: RABBI
dialogues.text: I'll store your office right here inside the front door. For free. Pete smiles.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: You and I seem to be the only two on this block that care about free stuff.

dialogues.speaker: RABBI
dialogues.text: Because we're the only two that realize that you can't buy what we have to offer. It's free. Pete and the rabbi place the desk, chair, and poster insi the synagogue. Pete shakes the rabbi's hand and rides his bike home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pete sits at his stand. The rabbi parks his car on the st 100 feet from Pete's stand. The rabbi doesn't want to blo Pete's storefront billboard. The rabbi steps out of his c His secretary, Julie, a pretty, voluptuous, middle aged w who obviously was waiting for the rabbi, walks out the do and greets the rabbi. Pete watches her.

dialogues.speaker: JULIE
dialogues.text: Rabbi Jacobsen, you've received six messages.

dialogues.speaker: RABBI
dialogues.text: Door to door service. Julie, I don't pay you enough. Julie hands the rabbi his telephone messages. The rabbi r them and laughs.

dialogues.speaker: JULIE
dialogues.text: Members of the congregation don't seem to think this stand is a laughing matter. It's against Judaism.

dialogues.speaker: RABBI
dialogues.text: Most of the members don't seem to notice this temple, except during the high holidays or when they need something. Pete's giving us free advertising.

dialogues.speaker: JULIE
dialogues.text: But he's advertising Christianity.

dialogues.speaker: RABBI
dialogues.text: No, he's advertising thought. He's asking people to have a cup of free lemonade with him and maybe get some insight into how to get to heaven. Doesn't seem like this neighborhood cares about that. I wish a thousand Pete's opened up stands on this street. Seamus rides his bike up to the stand.

dialogues.speaker: SEAMUS
dialogues.text: Hey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey. Seamus gets off his bike and pours himself a cup of lemon

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: Don't pour it all. Seamus looks around. As if there was a public stampede fo Pete's lemonade. Seamus waves to Rabbi Jacobsen. The rabb walks toward the stand.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: Rabbi Jacobsen, this is my older brother Seamus. He's nine. The rabbi shakes Seamus's hand.

dialogues.speaker: RABBI
dialogues.text: I'm Rabbi Jacobsen. I'm forty-four. How many are there?

dialogues.speaker: SEAMUS
dialogues.text: Eight. But my oldest brother might go to college, so then there will be seven. And maybe we'll get his room.

dialogues.speaker: RABBI
dialogues.text: Quite a flock.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: Got a dog too. Wanna cup of lemonade Rabbi?

dialogues.speaker: RABBI
dialogues.text: No thanks.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: Mam?

dialogues.speaker: JULIE
dialogues.text: No thank you.

dialogues.speaker: RABBI
dialogues.text: Well, you keep up the...

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG BOY
dialogues.text: Rabbi! Rabbi! A young boy comes running full speed around the corner.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG BOY
dialogues.text: Rabbi! Rabbi! The rabbi's face turns white.

dialogues.speaker: RABBI
dialogues.text: What is it Steven? The sounds of fire engines roaring fill the air. A huge f engine turns the corner and races past.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rabbi, your house is on fire. Big fire! The Rabbi doesn't hear the last line. He takes off in a f sprint back the way Steven came. Another fire engine race past. WE FOLLOW the fire engine. WE PASS OVER THE TOP of FIRE ENGINE to the other side where JOE O'MALLEY hangs on WE FOLLOW THE FIRE ENGINE up the block where people stand outside watching a house burn. The rabbi reaches the hous at the same time the fire engine does.

dialogues.speaker: RABBI
dialogues.text: My boys! Where are my boys? David? Danny? The rabbi furiously searches the crowd. Joe O'Malley reac the rabbi. A quick exchange between the two. The rabbi ta off toward the stairs of his house. Two other firemen cat him and hold him back. Joe motions to the firemen to pull him back and the rest of the crowd to the other side of t street. He grabs a couple of other firemen who aim the ho at the front door. Joe runs into the house and disappears into the smoke. A CLOSE SHOT on Pete and Seamus, who have been watching f the corner. Mrs. Jacobsen arrives. The rabbi grabs her. M Jacobsen starts to cry. Everyone watches for Joe to reapp with two boys in hands. The firemen hose the flames. The rabbi makes another run for the house, but this time poli hold him back. The rabbi goes limp as the two policemen h him up. The rabbi's eyes are fixated on the front door. W there is just smoke, the outline of Joe O'Malley appears. has a child, Danny, wrapped in a blanket in his arms. He runs down the stairs and across the street. He hands the off to the paramedics. Danny is suffering from smoke inhalation but is OK. His parents surround him. The rabbi screams at Joe. Joe can only read his lips. Dav David! My other boy! David! Joe looks back at the house. The flames rage uncontrollab and the other houses are now in danger of catching fire. rabbi grabs Joe by the shoulders and screams. This time J eyes are only on the fire. Joe takes off toward the house firemen tries to stop him but Joe bounces off him like a running back. As he reaches the front steps, an explosion knocks him back ten feet and flames roar out the front do Firemen trample Joe as his coat catches on fire. They sta out the fire while they hold him down. Joe rolls over and stares at the Jacobsens. Mrs. Jacobsen is hysterically cr as the rabbi stares aimlessly. The rabbi turns slowly and buries his wife's head in his chest. Danny, his youngest son, stares over his oxygen mask and up at his parents. J stands up and is escorted toward the ambulance as other firemen storm the house with more hoses. A CLOSE SHOT of PETE. His face is void of any emotion other than a look t says he thought his dad was dead. A CLOSE SHOT of SEAMUS. Tears stream down his face. As his dad clears the crowd a reaches the ambulance on his own two feet, Seamus takes o in a full sprint and covers the fifty yards in seconds. P stands still.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dad! Dad! Dad! Joe looks up and before he knows it Seamus is jumping int his arms. Joe puts Seamus down instantly and starts to scream.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: What the hell are you doing here? Jesus Christ Seamus! Jesus Christ! Seamus's face turns white. Joe looks up and sees Pete sta on the corner frozen.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: And you brought your brother? Joe slaps Seamus across the face.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: How many times have I told you not to chase fire engines! It's dangerous. You could have killed yourself and your brother. Go home! And wait for me in your room! Seamus turns around and walks toward Pete. Seamus reaches Pete, who is still frozen. Seamus never looks up from the pavement.

dialogues.speaker: SEAMUS
dialogues.text: Come on. Pete looks at his dad, who now sits on the back of the ambulance as paramedics care for him. Pete looks further Rabbi Jacobsen. Danny Jacobsen, six years old and bald, catches Pete's eye. They look at each other. Pete turns a walks away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The O'Malley family sits around the TV and watches the ne which is reporting live from the fire, which still simmer in the background. WE GO UP THE STAIRS AND DOWN THE HALLWAY to Pete and Seam room. They both sit on their beds staring quietly at the ceilin Seamus throws a tennis ball to himself. The front door op and screams of DAD fill the house. Pete turns and looks a Seamus. Seamus fixates on the rotation of the ball as it leaves his hand. He repeats this over and over. Joe enter the bedroom and closes the door behind him. Pete and Seamus sit up. Joe grabs a chair and flips it ar so he's leaning forward on the back of the chair.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: How many times have I told you boys?  Seamus begins to speak. Joe cuts him off.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: People die in fires. You don't chase fires, you run away from them. That family lost a ten year old boy in that fire today.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: Rabbi Jacobsen's son died? Joe nods.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: What were you two doing in that neighborhood? Pete and Seamus stay silent.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: You're both grounded. You can't leave this block. If I find either one of you outside this block or hear that either one of you left this block, you will get a whooping that you will still feel on your sixteenth birthday.

dialogues.speaker: SEAMUS
dialogues.text: But the baseball field...

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: That's it. Joe stands up and exits the room. Seamus gets off his bed and grabs his glove. He starts to pound the ball into his glove.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: I'm sorry. It's my fault. Seamus stares out the window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe sits in the backyard alone on a lounge chair drinking Old Style beer. A floodlight illuminates the backyard. Th backdoor opens and shuts. Joe continues to stare out. Pet grabs a chair, spins it around like his dad, and leans fo on the back of the chair. Nothing is said for a few seconds as Pete stares out. Joe doesn't look at Pete.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: What are you doing up?

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: Couldn't sleep. (Pause)  Joe takes Joe takes Joe takes Silence. Dad, Seamus was only in the area because he was checking up on me. a big sip from his beer.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: I'm on a quest. To meet a Jewish person and help them get to heaven. another sip from his beer.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Jewish people can't go to heaven.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: Mom says they can be converted. Through Jesus. I asked Father Kelly and he said that is the role of a good Christian. another sip.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: So I've been going over to the temple on Oakley. Looking for Jewish people. I met Rabbi Jacobsen. He's like a priest over at the synagogue. He's been real nice. And I feel really bad for him now that his son has died.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: How old are you?

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: Seven. And a half. You know.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: You should be playing baseball and going to the pool. And asleep by nine.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: Seamus was just seeing how things were going.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Don't go to that synagogue anymore. You go to church. Let the Jewish people take care of themselves.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: But I'm on a quest.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Not anymore. The Jews will be Jews. And Christians will be Christians. Don't try to change things at seven and a half. Pete stares out at the backyard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get to bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Margaret lays in bed watching "The Tonight Show" when Joe walks out of the bathroom. He jumps into bed and watches with her.

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: How bad was it? Joe shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: Joe, I can't raise these kids alone and I've gained too much weight to find a new husband. Joe laughs and squeezes her stomach.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Too much weight? You're skinnier and more beautiful than the first day I met you. Margaret laughs.

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: Your charm worked on me when I was a teenager. I see what I see. Tell me about the fire.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: It was a fire. They're never good. Margaret knocks on the wall that the bed lays against. Sh turns her head and faces the wall.

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: (sarcastic to the wall) Tell me about your day. (As wall) Well, it was a day like any other day. I stood firm, attached to the floor.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Whaddaya want from me?

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: Not the tough guy I'm being interviewed I did my job routine. Joe touches Margaret's stomach and rubs it.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: If you were skinnier when we met, I don't remember. And there's no way I  liked it. Margaret pushes his hand away and rolls over. Joe twists pillow in half and stares at the ceiling.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Did you know Pete was going to a synagogue to convert Jewish people? Margaret laughs.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: I'm not finding that as funny. Margaret rolls over and faces Joe.

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: Pete is searching for meaning in his life.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: He's seven. Baseball is the only meaning in a seven year old's life.

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: Some kids are destined for greater things than baseball.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: I don't know honey. Sounds like Pete's looking for a recipe to get beat up. I told him to leave those people alone. Don't let him go over there.

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: I can't watch these kid's every move. Molly needs my constant attention. All I know is he walks out of the house in the morning, and when he comes back, he's clean and nobody's calling to say he was trouble.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Now that's parenting 101. My kid's clean and nobody says he's trouble. Am I going to have to work and raise the kids?

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: Don 't start with me Joe. Margaret rolls over. Joe spoons up against her.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Maybe we should bring another kid into the world who's clean and doesn't cause any trouble?

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: Well, if you're looking for my womb, I think it fell out over there when I was dusting. Have at it.  Joe rolls back over and watches "The Tonight Show".

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe sits on a lounge chair outside of the firehouse with few other firemen playing cards. Roger, his brother and f fireman, is studying the sports page.

dialogues.speaker: ROGER
dialogues.text: The Sox hit lefties hard. Zisk loves lefties. No comments.

dialogues.speaker: ROGER
dialogues.text: I think you gotta take the Sox tonight plus one fifty. They're a good bet. A buck to win a buck fifty.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Why you try to convince us? You never bet against the Sox. Ever.

dialogues.speaker: ROGER
dialogues.text: I like their lineup. It's explosive.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: You ever think about betting the other team. When you're betting, don't let your heart get in the way of a good decision.

dialogues.speaker: ROGER
dialogues.text: Yeah, but when your heart and mind are in together, it's a sure bet.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Funny how your heart and mind always say Sox.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Gin! Joe throws his cards down.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Shut the hell up Roger. Jack's crushing me cause of you. (To Jack) You should be a garbage man the way you pick up every card I throw. You do that to piss me off, Jack? Jack adds the score.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: I do it to win. Five hundred to two twenty. At a nickel a point. Fourteen bucks you owe me. Joe goes into his pocket and fishes out fourteen dollars. Rabbi Jacobsen walks up the driveway with his son Danny. rabbi has two tinfoiled trays and Danny carries two bottl of red wine.

dialogues.speaker: RABBI
dialogues.text: Gentlemen. The men get quiet. Joe walks over to help the rabbi with trays. Roger takes the wine from Danny.

dialogues.speaker: RABBI
dialogues.text: My wife, my son, and I wanted to thank you for your bravery and kindness. The rabbi looks down at Danny. Danny's White Sox hat cove his bald head.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Thank you. The men, still quiet, nod. Jack takes a tray from Joe and the other tray from the rabbi. Joe puts out his hand.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Rabbi, Joe O'Malley. I'm sorry for your loss. The men nod in agreement.

dialogues.speaker: RABBI
dialogues.text: Thank you. My son David was a good boy. The rabbi looks at the shiny red fire trucks.

dialogues.speaker: RABBI
dialogues.text: He loved you firemen. Never understood why I couldn't be a fireman on the side and park the firetruck outside the house. The men laugh. Danny smiles. Joe nudges Roger and points his head. Roger nods knowingly and walks into the firehou

dialogues.speaker: RABBI
dialogues.text: My wife figures the best way to thank a man is through his stomach. She baked some lasagna for all of you in appreciation.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: It's real good. Joe looks at Danny.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: I bet it is. (To Rabbi) My guys love a good meal, but I wish your wife wouldn't have. We were  just doing our job.

dialogues.speaker: RABBI
dialogues.text: A heroic job you do. My wife wanted to thank you personally. My synagogue will want to thank you formally. Joe looks down. Not heroic enough to save your other son, Joe thinks.

dialogues.speaker: RABBI
dialogues.text: I don't know if you're allowed to drink red wine on the job, but lasagna just isn't as good without a fine wine.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Nothing is as good without a fine wine. Roger comes back with a plastic firehat and button.

dialogues.speaker: ROGER
dialogues.text: This is for you. A deputy fire chief. Danny takes off his White Sox hat and hands it to his dad He puts on the firehat.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: ROGER
dialogues.text: You're welcome. You a big Sox fan?

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Huge. Zisk crushes the ball.

dialogues.speaker: ROGER
dialogues.text: Especially against lefties. You wanna check out the firetruck? Danny looks at his dad excitedly, His dad nods. Roger tak Danny by the hand and walks back into the firehouse. The other men follow. Joe stays out with Rabbi Jacobsen. The rabbi breaks the silence.

dialogues.speaker: RABBI
dialogues.text: It is Jewish custom to sit chiva at the house of the deceased. It is a sign of support to the family of the deceased.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Like a wake.

dialogues.speaker: RABBI
dialogues.text: Yes, like a wake. I know you are a busy man, but if you have time, I would be honored if you could stop by and sit for a few minutes with my family and friends.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You bet.

dialogues.speaker: RABBI
dialogues.text: Obviously, it is not at my home. But at my brothers on 2243 Damen.

dialogues.speaker: RABBI
dialogues.text: Anytime after seven PM all week. Danny is on the back of the truck.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Dad! Check me out!

dialogues.speaker: RABBI
dialogues.text: Children realize life is about living. And death is about life. Do you have any children of your own? Joe laughs. Joe rolls

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Yep. I've got children all right. Eight.

dialogues.speaker: RABBI
dialogues.text: Eight? A blessed man. his eyes as if the blessing isn't always so.

dialogues.speaker: RABBI
dialogues.text: The O'Malley clan? By any chance, is a beautiful young redhead named Pete yours? Joe nods in embarrassment.

dialogues.speaker: RABBI
dialogues.text: Your bravery has been passed on. He's the most earnest, delightful young man I have ever met.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: I found out he's been a nuisance at your temple and I've reprimanded him. He won't be bothering you anymore.

dialogues.speaker: RABBI
dialogues.text: Your son is a welcome sight at the temple. Danny screams as he sits in the rear driving seat. Joe an the rabbi look at Danny.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Do you mind if I ask?  Joe points to his head.

dialogues.speaker: RABBI
dialogues.text: Luekemia. Chemotherapy.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: I'm sorry. So sorry.

dialogues.speaker: RABBI
dialogues.text: God has a plan. A mysterious plan for my family. Joe and the rabbi watch Danny.

dialogues.speaker: RABBI
dialogues.text: If you can find time, we would love to have you at my brother's house. Bring Pete. It would be good for everyone spirits to see a child so full of life like your son. Joe smiles.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: He's full of something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pete and Seamus lay on the floor playing "All Star Baseba Katie dances around to music from the record player. Baby Molly sleeps in the crib. Patrick walks in the door with day's mail. Katie runs over and grabs the mail from him.

dialogues.speaker: KATIE
dialogues.text: Getting the mail is my job. She punches him, hands over the mail to Katie, who takes over to the table. She rifles through the mail. Katie can read.

dialogues.speaker: KATIE
dialogues.text: Bill! Bill! Bill! Looks like all bills. Katie gets up and starts to dance. Patrick sits down and looks at the mail. A few pieces of official mail are addr to him. Patrick opens them up and reads them. Patrick cru the paper and leaves it on the table. He walks away from table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The family sits at the dinner table. Tommy and Eddie are missing from the table. The kids eat pot roast and roaste potatoes.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: The boys game started at six?  Joe looks Joe nods. Joe looks Pete nods.

dialogues.speaker: SEAMUS
dialogues.text: Doubleheader. Uncle Roger, Billy, and Roger junior are going. at Margaret. She nods.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: You finish your chores?

dialogues.speaker: SEAMUS
dialogues.text: Yep. Pete looks at his dad.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Rabbi Jacobsen invited you and me to a... a... chivas at his house.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: Rabbi Jacobsen? Chivas?

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Yep. Like a wake. I told him we would be there. at Margaret. She smiles.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: How's he doing?

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: It's gotta be tough.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: We'll go and then catch the second game.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: Yeah. We'll do that.

dialogues.speaker: SEAMUS
dialogues.text: Tell Rabbi Jacobsen I'm sorry for him.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: I will.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: You know he's got a boy your age. I met him today. He'll be there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe and Margaret still sit at the table. Joe drinks a bee while Margaret drinks coffee. Mary rocks Molly. Seamus st at the sink scraping food and washing dishes. He hands th to Pete, who stands on a stool and rinses the dishes. Pe hands the dishes to Katie, who places the dishes in the dishwasher.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: The rabbi's other kid has leukemia.

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: We've been blessed. I don't know how we've been so lucky, but I'm not to question it.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Stupid electrical wiring. Those damn old houses weren't built for modern wiring. Patrick walks by.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Hey, lifesaver, why don't you sit down? Patrick takes a seat.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: So, your mother thinks you got some news? Patrick plays with his fork.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: Maybe I'll take a look at the job over at the city planners office. Joe pauses.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: It's a good job with nice benefits. I'll talk to Alderman McManus about it. Patrick stays silent.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Well, don't go there with that attitude. The alderman's doing us a favor. So don't go acting like a punk. From the kitchen, Katie mimics her dad.

dialogues.speaker: KATIE
dialogues.text: Yeah, don't go acting like a punk. Patrick stays silent.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: A lot of kids your age don't have a chance like this.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: A lot of kids my age go to college.  Not to work.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Yeah, and when they graduate, they're four years behind you in the working world. All they've learned from college is how to smoke pot and sleep.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: The good jobs nowadays require a college degree.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: A city job is a good job, and all it requires is hard work and a good attitude.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: The Irish way. Get a city job, work hard, have forty kids, retire on a crap pension in the same house you lived in all your life.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: You wanna be some hotshot bigshot, have one point two kids, live in the suburbs in a big house with no love to fill a closet, and retire to Florida to die like a raisin?

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: Yeah, what if do?

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Then go ahead. Be like the Jews. Have no more than two kids because it's not economical to have more. Make every decision based on money. Raise your kids to base their life on the size of their wallet. Raise them to worship the almighty dollar, not God.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: No, Dad, I shouldn't raise my kids to base their worth on the size of their wallet when I can teach them to base it on how much booze they can handle without puking. Joe gets up and cracks Patrick. The kids run to their mom

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: You ungrateful, smartass prick. You got all the answers at eighteen, don't you?

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: No, but maybe if I work a city fucking job, I'll have all the answers at forty. Joe cracks Patrick upside the head and knocks him over. T kids scream. Patrick gets up. He thinks about charging h dad, but decides to walk out of the kitchen and out of th house. The kids cry. Margaret shakes her head. Joe finish his beer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pete and Joe drive in the wagon. The White Sox broadcast blares from the radio. They drive in silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pete and Joe enter the house. A lot of people sit quietly The rabbi's brother greets them.

dialogues.speaker: JEFFREY
dialogues.text: I'm Jeffrey Jacobsen, Kenny's brother. We're glad you could make it. Pete hands Jeffrey some flowers. The room is void of any flowers. Jeffrey looks around for a place to put the flowers.

dialogues.speaker: JEFFREY
dialogues.text: I'll bring this in the kitchen. Thanks. Can I get you anything to drink?

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Scotch.

dialogues.speaker: JEFFREY
dialogues.text: I'll check to see if I have any scotch. If not?

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: A beer.

dialogues.speaker: JEFFREY
dialogues.text: I'll check to see if I have any beer. If not?

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: You know what, I'm fine.

dialogues.speaker: JEFFREY
dialogues.text: You sure?

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Yeah, I'm sure. Thanks. Jeffrey looks at Pete.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: No thanks. People sit on the couch. A picture of David sits prominen on the table. A handsome young boy. Joe works his way ove to Mrs. Jacobsen, who sits on the couch. Mrs. Jacobsen, pretty but plain dark haired woman, shakes Joe's hand.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: I am sorry for your loss, Mrs. Jacobsen.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. JACOBSEN
dialogues.text: Thank you. Pete stands quietly next to his dad. A gentlemen gets up from the couch facing Mrs. Jacobsen and motions for Pete Joe to sit. They sit. Small, quiet conversations take pla around them. Pete and Joe sit quietly. Rabbi Jacobsen ent the room with Danny. He walks over to Joe, who has stood to greet the rabbi. Joe puts out his hand. The rabbi shak his hand, but also moves in to hug Joe. Joe moves in unexpectedly for the hug. The rabbi picks up Pete and hug him. Pete laughs.

dialogues.speaker: RABBI
dialogues.text: My family is grateful to you. Joe nods. Danny waves to Joe. Joe waves to him. Danny loo at Pete.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: You wanna check out my room that I'm sharing with my cousin? Pete looks at his dad. Joe gives him the OK. Pete and Dan take off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Danny shows Pete his autographed glove. Sandy Koufax!

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: My dad says it's rare cause Mr. Koufax rarely signed things.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: Yeah. Was he good?

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: I think so. Danny hands Pete another glove.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: This was my brothers. You wanna play catch?

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: In the house? Danny grabs a tennis ball.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Yeah. It's just a tennis ball.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure. Danny fires a strike.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: How'd you lose your hair?

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Leukemia. It's cancer. I take this medicine that makes me lose my hair.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: Does it hurt?

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: No. The hair just fell out. I used to have black hair.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: I've got red hair.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: My friend Charlie's got red hair. They throw the ball back and forth.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: I'm sorry about your brother.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Thanks. You know, since my cancer, he didn't beat me up as much. We had fun together. Do you have any brothers?

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: Four older brothers.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Wow. You must get your butt kicked? Pete nods.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: My older sister's worse. My brothers just punch me in the gut. She pulls my hair. That hurts. I wish I were bald then. Danny smiles.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: Was the fire scary?

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: I don't know what happened. David was watching cartoons in the TV room. I was upstairs playing baseball. And then I noticed a lot of smoke. I opened my door but there was a lot of fire. I tried to open my window, but I couldn't. I couldn't see the  fire anymore because the smoke got so thick. And then your dad came in. He saved my life, I think. It was nothing like the fire drills you do in school.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: Where do you go to school?

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Briarwood. How ‘bout you?

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: Holy Cross. Going into third grade.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: I'm going into second. I missed a lot of first grade with all of the chemotherapy. That's what they call the cancer medicine. The boys throw the ball back and forth.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: What's it like to be Jewish?

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: I don't know. Good.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: I'm Catholic.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: What's that like?

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: Noisier.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Things are usually noisier around here. But everyone's really sad.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: My Uncle Jim died a few weeks ago. He was old. He was really my grandfather's brother, but we still called him Uncle Jim.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: I got an uncle like that. Harvey.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: You would have thought my uncle's funeral was a birthday party.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Sounds like fun.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: Yeah it is. My mom says that people are sad because they love the person, but are happy cause they get to go to heaven. Jewish people can't go to  heaven.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Why not?

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: Cause they're Jewish. God doesn't let Jewish people in heaven. Danny's quiet.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: If you're interested, I think I can show you how to get to heaven.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Yeah?

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: Yep. I would just have to convert you.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: How do you do that?

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: I don't know. I haven't converted anyone before.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: What can I do in heaven?

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: Anything you want. They call it paradise.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Sounds good. When can we start?

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: Tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: I got my last chemotherapy treatment on Friday. So that gives us all week.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: Fine. Let's meet at your dad's synagogue.

dialogues.speaker: OK.
dialogues.text: The boys toss the ball back and forth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pete and Joe sit in the wagon.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Danny's a good kid, huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. His medicine makes him bald. But it doesn't hurt. I'm gonna convert him. Joe shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Leave him alone.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: He wants to.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: But his parents don't. Look, he's Jewish. His family's Jewish. If they wanted to be Christian, his parents would change.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: But it's a quest.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: The quest has been called off.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: I promised Danny. We're meeting at the synagogue.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Well, I'm breaking that promise. You can't go converting Jewish kids the same way they don't go converting you.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: But he wants to.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: I said no. No more lip from you. Do not go to that synagogue and do not bother Danny or his family anymore. Do you understand me? Pete doesn't answer.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Do you understand me? If I find out you've been going over there, you will get the spanking of a lifetime and be grounded until you're sixteen. Do you understand?

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: Yes. The lights of the local baseball field illuminate the nig Joe turns into the parking lot.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: Danny, with his White Sox hat covering his bald head, st outside the synagogue. DIFFERENT SHOTS of Danny waiting. Danny finally decides Pete is not showing up. He gets on bike and turns the corner back toward his uncle's house. he passes an alley, Pete pops out and almost scares Danny off his bike. Pete sneaks back into the alley.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: What are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: Our quest has to be done in secret. Our mission is now undercover.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: Cause.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: What's our mission?

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: To get you to heaven.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Right. How we gonna know I got to heaven?

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: We'll just know.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: So what are we gonna do?

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: We got to set up some tests.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Like school.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: Yeah. But those tests aren't fun. What's the purpose of making it to heaven if the tests aren't fun?

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Have you taken any of these tests? Pete thinks.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: Since I'm Catholic, I don't think I have to. It's just automatic.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: That's cool.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: Yeah. But you know what. For my first communion next year, I have to  complete first communion training.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: What's communion?

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: This piece of bread that is Jesus.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: And you eat it?

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: Yep.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Gross.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: I watch people eat it and they don't gross out. And my brothers say it tastes like wheat bread.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Not as good as white. So I should do the first communion training.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: I haven't done it yet, so I don't know what it is.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Darn.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: But we can make up our own. The kids think.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: How about something like Bruce Jenner and a decathlon? Win the decathlon, go to heaven. Pete thinks.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: Yeah, something like that.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: And then we should have a gold medal ceremony. Gotta have a medal.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: Communion can be your medal.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: The Jesus wheat bread?

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: I'd rather have a medal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We can talk about it later. Let's go, we can't be spotted.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Why can't we spotted?

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: We're undercover.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pete and Danny sit on the Elevated Train that runs from Chicago's north side to its south side. Pete looks out th window. They pass a car wash. Danny looks up and down the aisle.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: My parents don't let me on the El without them.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: Father Kelly always talks about a risk reward. I think you'll be OK if your parents find out. We'll just explain the risk was worth the reward.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The beach is pretty full. Lake Michigan's waves crash wea against the rocks. Gymnastic rings are set up at the nort side of the beach along with an area filled with weights. Elevated five feet above the beach is a paved area for ru and bikers.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: If we see my sister, just start running.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: How am I gonna know it's your sister?

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: I'll be running.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Right. The boys look around. Two teenage girls in bikinis walk p them. The boys smile. The girls smile back. Danny does his best  Fonz impression. Pete laughs.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: Bruce Jenner is faster, stronger, and can jump higher than anyone else. So that's how we should do this.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: OK. I'm fast.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: But first, you need to be baptized. My baby sister just got baptized. We all got baptized. I don't remember mine, but I've seen pictures. Danny nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pete is trying to pick up Danny by his ankles. He lifts D up and they both fall into the water. Pete, determined to it right, then grabs Danny by the ankles and lifts. Danny head, along with his shoulders, wade back and forth in th water.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: Amen! Pete lets go of Danny's legs and Danny crashes completely into the water. Pete falls in also. They both wipe away t water from their faces.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: I think it would have been easier if you were a baby.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Let's get started. What should we do first?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A SERIES OF SHOTS. Pete counting as Danny runs toward him Danny hanging from a ring as Pete counts him down. Pete a Danny talking to a man with weights. Danny trying to lift the weight. He can't. Pete tries. He can't. They take off some of the weight. D lifts the weight over his head. Danny climbs a small hill rocks. Pete waits for him at the bottom, about six feet b Danny jumps, hits the sand, and rolls.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pete and Danny alternating turns drinking from a thermos.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nine down. One to go.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: This one's gotta be tough.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Some of those were tough.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: Yeah, but the last one's gotta be real tough. Something that takes strength, speed, and courage.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: I don't know.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: What can't you do well?

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: I'm not a strong swimmer. Pete looks out to Lake Michigan. A buoy signals the spot where the lifeguards don't want you to swim past.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: Swim out to the buoy. Danny looks for the buoy.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: I can't even see the buoy. Pete points to it.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: I can't get there.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: You're going to have to if you wanna win the decathlon. Pete and Danny head toward the water.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: Look, I'm not asking you to do something I can't. When I was your age, I could swim to the buoy.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Do I have to get to the buoy and back under a certain amount of time. Pete looks at the buoy. He looks at Danny.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: What do you think?

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: Getting there and back is enough. Danny smiles.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: Don't worry. I'm here. And there are lifeguards everywhere. Danny starts swimming. He dips his head in the water and slowly one arm dives in the water while one arm raises ou of the water. He brings his whole head out of the water t breathe, dips his head in the water, and repeats the proc Halfway to the buoy, he tries to pick his head up to see where the buoy is. He begins to sink and panics. His arms start to flail. Pete dives into the water as Danny turns body so he can float on his back. Pete reaches Danny and grabs him.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: You OK?

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: I couldn't make it. And then I remembered what my swim teacher taught me about floating. But I don't think I could float there and back.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: No, I don't think so either. Can you make it back? Danny nods and rolls over to his front. Danny starts swim in and Pete follows him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pete and Danny sit on the El. Danny's dejected.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: In one day you passed nine tests. God's gotta be happy with you.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Yeah, but I don't know how I'm gonna pass the last one. That's tough.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: Look, we got all week. Trust me. You can do it.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: I hope so. I really want to go to heaven.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: You will. Do kids die from what you have? Danny nods.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: The first time I took chemotherapy, two other boys and a girl took it with me. When they started me on it a second time, I was the only one. The others died.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: How do you know?

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: I asked. The nurses got all quiet. Grown ups always get quiet when they talk about death.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: Not at my uncle's funeral.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Sometimes I hear my parents talk about it late at night and they cry. I feel so bad. And now with my brother, my mom cries all day and night. I don't want her to be so sad if I die.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: No, I wouldn't want that either.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: So if I can convince her that I'm going to paradise, maybe she won't be so sad. Pete nods. The boys look out the window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Danny swims out toward the buoy. He doesn't make it. He f and waits for Pete. He follows Pete back to the shore.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: I don't understand. You look like you're going to get there, and then you don't.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: I don't know.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: But you swim back to shore fine with me.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: I know.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: So what is it?

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: I look up to see where the buoy is, and I can't see it. And then I start  to realize how far out I am and...

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: What if I go with you?

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: No. I gotta do it alone.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: Well maybe if you don't look up.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: But then I don't know where I am.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: We'll figure this out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Danny puts on the goggles. But he still can't do it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pete puts on the goggles. He looks out toward the buoy.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: I can see fine. Pete hands the goggles to Danny. Danny puts them on and l toward the buoy.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: I can see it from here. But when I get in the water, I can't see it and then everything starts getting really fast and I can't go any further. Pete plays with the sand. Danny scoops sand and throws it

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: Stand up. Danny stands. Pete raises Danny's hands over his head. Pe then raises his hands over his head. He measures the difference.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: You stay here and watch me swim to the buoy. I'll be right back. Pete swims out to the buoy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pete swims ashore.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: It took me fifty strokes there, and fifty five strokes back. One hundred and five strokes.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: So?

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: Your problem is when you look up and you can't see the buoy, you get scared and panic.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: I don't get scared.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: Yeah you do.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: No I don't.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: Listen. All you have to do is count your strokes. You don't need to look up. Can you count to fifty?

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: Well, I'ma little bigger so it's going to take you a few more strokes. Can you count to sixty?

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Yep.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: Well then, just count to sixty strokes and then swim back. It might take you a few more strokes on the way back.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: I can do that. But I'm real tired and I need to get back for my treatment this afternoon.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: Right. Tomorrow. Tomorrow you complete the decathlon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Danny sitting in a chair with IV's stuck in him. He's wat the White Sox. Through the door window, a doctor speaks t Rabbi Jacobsen and his wife.

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR
dialogues.text: This last treatment will weaken his immune system greatly. The red blood  cells don't seem to be responding, so we upped the dosage.

dialogues.speaker: RABBI
dialogues.text: What's the prognosis?

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR
dialogues.text: I don't know. If this treatment doesn't work, I don't think there's anymore we can do.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. JACOBSEN
dialogues.text: Why? Isn't there a stronger dosage or more intensive treatment?

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR
dialogues.text: This is the most intensive treatment. And a stronger dosage would kill him. Mrs. Jacobsen goes to speak but the rabbi grabs her hand. squeezes it. The Jacobsen's enter the room.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: The Sox are getting clobbered Dad.

dialogues.speaker: RABBI
dialogues.text: They've been getting clobbered all my life.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Mine too. The rabbi squeezes his wife's hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pete sits in the a doorway hidden from plain sight. The r walks up to Pete.

dialogues.speaker: RABBI
dialogues.text: Danny told me I might find you here.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: I don't know how he knew I would be here. The rabbi smiles.

dialogues.speaker: RABBI
dialogues.text: Danny wanted me to tell you that he wouldn't be able to complete the decathlon today. Pete stares at the Rabbi, hoping to be able to figure out how much the rabbi knows.

dialogues.speaker: RABBI
dialogues.text: You see, the medicine Danny's taking...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chemotherapy .

dialogues.speaker: RABBI
dialogues.text: Yep. Chemotherapy. It zaps him of his strength. And weakens his ability to fight off disease.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: Sounds like bad medicine.

dialogues.speaker: RABBI
dialogues.text: Yes it does. But that's how doctors fight cancer.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: My oldest brother wants to become a doctor. My mom always tells me to do my homework so I can be smart and become a doctor.

dialogues.speaker: RABBI
dialogues.text: It's a noble profession.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: My dad thinks they play too much golf. And they charge like assholes.

dialogues.speaker: RABBI
dialogues.text: I hate to disagree with your dad, but he probably wouldn't want you using that word.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: Seamus says you can use swear words if you're quoting someone.

dialogues.speaker: RABBI
dialogues.text: Seamus sounds like a fine journalist. Is your oldest brother going to college to study medicine?

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: No. He can't afford college.

dialogues.speaker: RABBI
dialogues.text: Higher education is expensive. But worth it if you work hard.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: Rabbi, when do you think Danny will be better?

dialogues.speaker: RABBI
dialogues.text: I did not study medicine in college, but even if I did, I don't think I could answer that. It's in God's hands now.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: Well, you're close with God. Hopefully that rubs off a little on Danny. I hope he gets better, we've got some  unfinished business.

dialogues.speaker: RABBI
dialogues.text: I hope so too. Praying for Danny is all we can do now.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: OK. I'll pray to Jesus, you pray to God, and hopefully somebody listens.

dialogues.speaker: RABBI
dialogues.text: That's a deal. Pete jumps on his bike.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: See ya later Rabbi Jacobsen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pete sits by himself in a pew at church. Father Kelly, 71 snow white hair, skin cancered face, cantankerous old man notices Pete and walks over.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER
dialogues.text: Mr. O'Malley? Are you lost?

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: Hey Father. No, I promised a friend I'd pray for him. He's sick.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER
dialogues.text: Well, maybe I can say a prayer for him also. Father Kelly sits down next to Pete.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: His name's Danny. He's got cancer. Father Kelly does the sign of the cross. He closes his ey Pete stares at him. Father Kelly opens one eye at Pete.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER
dialogues.text: You finish your prayer? Pete nods.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER
dialogues.text: Well, let me finish my prayers without you bothering me. Pete stands up and walks toward the altar. Father Kelly watches him.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER
dialogues.text: Where are you going?

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: Just checking out how this place looks from your seat. Pete takes a seat in a chair to the left of the altar. F Kelly stands and walks toward the altar.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER
dialogues.text: That's my seat. Don't mess it up.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: You get nervous with everyone looking at you?

dialogues.speaker: FATHER
dialogues.text: I'm used to being looked at.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: You ever get nervous that you won't know what to say or you'll forget what you wanted to say?

dialogues.speaker: FATHER
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: How do you get paid?

dialogues.speaker: FATHER
dialogues.text: That's between me and the IRS.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: Do you get the collection money?

dialogues.speaker: FATHER
dialogues.text: No. Someone tell you I did? Pete shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER
dialogues.text: Do you need to get home? Pete shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: Your job's to help people to get to heaven, right? Father Kelly nods.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: How do you know if you've done your job good?

dialogues.speaker: FATHER
dialogues.text: Well. I pray that I do it well. why? You have any complaints?

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: You ever actually seen someone in heaven? Father Kelly shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: Then how do you know if the people  you're helping made it to heaven?

dialogues.speaker: FATHER
dialogues.text: Faith.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: Faith?

dialogues.speaker: FATHER
dialogues.text: Yep. Believing in something completely without actually having proof of it. Faith. I don't have any proof of heaven, but I have faith it exists.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: What's the best way to get to heaven?

dialogues.speaker: FATHER
dialogues.text: By believing in Jesus and doing as he taught us.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: How do we know if we're doing that? Is there some test?

dialogues.speaker: FATHER
dialogues.text: Life is a test.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: But then you need to die to figure out how you did on the test? Father Kelly laughs. He nods. He opens the altar and fill the chalice with hosts.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: Don't you just once want to know if one of the people you prayed for made it to heaven?

dialogues.speaker: FATHER
dialogues.text: In due time. Father Kelly finishes filling the chalice with bread.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: What's the purpose of communion?

dialogues.speaker: FATHER
