dialogues.text: To have a piece of Jesus be a part of us.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: Why do I have to wait till third grade for that? Wouldn't that help me now?

dialogues.speaker: FATHER
dialogues.text: The Church believes that Catholics should fulfill a few requirements before they earn communion.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: Pete runs Like passing a few tests?

dialogues.speaker: FATHER
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: So if I pass all the tests, I get to have communion.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: Thanks Father. You've cleared up a few things for me. off the altar.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER
dialogues.text: Good, glad the grilling is over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The family sits around the table.

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: Rabbi Jacobsen wanted to see if he could stop by after work. I said fine. Pete's eyes light up but he doesn't want to say anything that would get him in trouble.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: This gratitude stuff is becoming intrusive.

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: If the only fault you can find with a person is that they go overboard with kindness and gratitude, I can live with that.

dialogues.speaker: KATIE
dialogues.text: Me too.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Yeah. Yeah. (To Patrick's chair) Where's knucklehead?

dialogues.speaker: KATIE
dialogues.text: He said he'd be home late for dinner.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Oh yeah. Did he say why?

dialogues.speaker: KATIE
dialogues.text: He told me to mind my own business.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: He's probably sitting on his ass reading a book in that lifeguard tower. Where the others?

dialogues.speaker: SEAMUS
dialogues.text: Tommy and Eddie have a game up north. Another doubleheader. And Mary's eating at a friends. The doorbell rings. Pete and Katie run to get it. Pete le Katie open the door. Rabbi Jacobsen stands with a tray of rugala, a Jewish pastry.

dialogues.speaker: RABBI
dialogues.text: Hello. I know Pete, and whom may I ask are you? Katie puts her hand out. The rabbi goes to shake her hand but she put her hand out to take the tray.

dialogues.speaker: RABBI
dialogues.text: This might be too big for you.

dialogues.speaker: KATIE
dialogues.text: I handle bigger trays than that in the kitchen. How do you think I feed eight kids? The Rabbi nods and hands the dish to Katie. She carries i into the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: How's Danny doing?

dialogues.speaker: RABBI
dialogues.text: He's doing better. Still not ready to play but he said to say hi and he'll stop by to see you when he can play again. Pete looks back to see if his dad heard that. He didn't.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: Come on in. We're just eating dinner. The rabbi follows Pete into the kitchen. Seamus sits eati his potatoes. He stands up and shakes the rabbi's hand.

dialogues.speaker: SEAMUS
dialogues.text: Rabbi Jacobsen.

dialogues.speaker: RABBI
dialogues.text: Seamus. Nice to see you. Joe stands up and shakes the rabbi's hand. The rabbi walk over and says hello to Margaret and pats little Molly on head.

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: Would you like some dinner? There's plenty. The rabbi looks at the well sliced pieces of ham and huge  bowl of mashed potatoes.

dialogues.speaker: RABBI
dialogues.text: No thank you. My wife knows when I've been eating other people's dinner. She considers it a form of adultery. Margaret laughs.

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: How ‘bout some coffee?

dialogues.speaker: RABBI
dialogues.text: Sure. Katie stands up and walks toward the coffee pot.

dialogues.speaker: KATIE
dialogues.text: Black? Cream? Sugar?

dialogues.speaker: RABBI
dialogues.text: Two sugars. Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: KATIE
dialogues.text: You're welcome.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Please sit. The rabbi takes a seat at the table.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: How's your little boy?

dialogues.speaker: RABBI
dialogues.text: Hanging in there, thank you. He just finished more treatment and hopefully this works.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: We hope so too. Margaret comes back with the rugala on a plate. Katie han the rabbi his coffee. Margaret takes a bite of the rugala

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: It's absolutely delicious. The rabbi takes a little.

dialogues.speaker: RABBI
dialogues.text: She can't get mad at me if I'm eating her own stuff. Rugala, a Jewish pastry. My favorite. Margaret hands the rugala out to the boys and Joe. They'r all very happy.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: So what's going on?

dialogues.speaker: RABBI
dialogues.text: Well, remember when I told you that my congregation will want to formally thank you for your bravery.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: There's no need, Rabbi. And that's the end of that.

dialogues.speaker: RABBI
dialogues.text: Well, maybe Margaret and you would like to talk about it more in private? Joe looks at the boys. Seamus's busy eating his rugala an Pete stares at the rabbi.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: That's OK.

dialogues.speaker: RABBI
dialogues.text: Well, you personally showed bravery beyond the call of duty when you saved Danny, and if it weren't for the gas pipe blowing up, you were going back in against the wishes of your partners. Joe is embarrassed and quiet.

dialogues.speaker: RABBI
dialogues.text: The firemen saved the fire from spreading and many of the people from my temple live in that neighborhood. Patrick enters the front door. He walks into the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: Patrick, I would like you to meet Rabbi Jacobsen.

dialogues.speaker: RABBI
dialogues.text: Patrick, your brother Peter has told me much about you. Nice to meet you. They shake hands.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: Nice to meet you, Rabbi. I'm sorry for your loss.

dialogues.speaker: RABBI
dialogues.text: Thank you. Well, Patrick, I was just telling your father that my temple would like to say thank you to him. And it might interest you. Patrick sits down.

dialogues.speaker: RABBI
dialogues.text: Pete has told me of your wish to go to college and study medicine. Patrick looks at Pete. Joe looks at Pete. Pete knows his dad's look is not the same as Patrick's and Pete looks d

dialogues.speaker: RABBI
dialogues.text: My temple gives educational scholarships to deserving students, and the scholarship board has recommended Patrick for a full scholarship to a state university. Patrick's jaw drops. Margaret sits shocked and Joe stands up.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Rabbi Jacobsen, that is an extremely kind offer, but one that we cannot accept. Patrick looks at Joe and tears form in his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: RABBI
dialogues.text: It would mean a lot to our congregation and personally to my family if you would accept it.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Other men risked their lives that day and every other day.

dialogues.speaker: RABBI
dialogues.text: We understand that. But, to be frank, it's more personal than say giving the fire department a sculpture in gratitude. Your fire chief approved it.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: You spoke to my boss?

dialogues.speaker: RABBI
dialogues.text: Yes. We wanted to make sure it was within the rules. The scholarship board can only grant one scholarship, and when Pete told me of Patrick's desire, I recommended Patrick.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: I imagine they want to give it to him in a big ceremony?

dialogues.speaker: RABBI
dialogues.text: Yes, I would imagine so. I think it would be a good public gesture.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Free publicity for the temple. Patrick stands up at that last comment.

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: Joe!

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Rabbi, thank you for stopping over.  The rabbi My son Pete has a big mouth, and my family doesn't need your handouts. We thank you for your kindness.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: You can't do this to me.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: You will shut your mouth. stands from the table. He thanks Margaret and Katie for the coffee. The rabbi door. The rabbi Joe looks

dialogues.speaker: RABBI
dialogues.text: I did not mean to cause any harm.

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: Rabbi, you have been anything but harmful. Thank you. pats Pete and Seamus on the head. He heads for the

dialogues.speaker: RABBI
dialogues.text: Mr. O'Malley. I did not intend for this to be thought of as a handout or a payout. But I did hope it would serve as a steppingstone for our two communities to come together. Have a good night. walks out the front door.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: You're so proud that you won't let me accept it.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: You have done nothing to deserve it. It's a publicity stunt.

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: It is not a publicity stunt. It is returning an act of kindness with an act of kindness.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: Dad, the rabbi is the nicest man in the world. at Pete furiously.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: You have a big mouth. You tell the rabbi that we don't have enough food to eat? Maybe he'll set up a food drive for our family?

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: I never said that. We talk a lot.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: I thought I told you to leave those  people alone? Pete stays quiet. Pete puts

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: You've been going to the temple? his head down.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: You disobeyed my orders.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: I was on a quest. To get Danny to heaven. And we're almost there.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: On a quest for heaven? By disobeying me, all you have done is put yourself on the road to hell. Go to your room and don't come out 'till I tell you to. Pete starts to cry.

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: Joe!

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: I was just trying to do the right thing.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: (To Margaret) He disobeyed my word. (To Pete) The right thing? You're not even eight. You don't know what the right thing is. You know what I tell you, and what your mother tells you. Jewish people believe in their own thing. They do not go to heaven. And neither do Christians who disobey their fathers. Now get upstairs. Now! Pete walks up the stairs. Joe walks into the kitchen and grabs a beer. Patrick follows him.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: I'm going to see the rabbi myself and work out a deal.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Over my dead body. Do you understand it's not about you? It's not about kindness. It's about good publicity. The Jews help out a poor Irish Catholic family and they get on the news and the people think, how nice is it that the Jews share their money.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: Why are you so cynical? You're too  proud to take a handout?

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Too proud? Maybe a little pride wouldn't hurt you. Instead of sitting there with your hand out, maybe if you took pride in a little hard work, you'd understand.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: There you go again. I work hard. My dad worked hard. You will work hard. I will work hard. At school. To get a good job.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Bullshit! We are not discussing this anymore tonight. I didn't spend my day at the beach. I'm tired!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Patrick begins to speak. Joe gets in his face and puts hi finger in Patrick's face.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: No more! No more! Patrick storms out of the kitchen. He stops to look at hi mother, who holds Molly in her arms.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: How can you just stand there? You're married to an asshole and you just stand there like this innocent bystander. Joe rushes into the living room.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: You will not speak to your mother like that. Get the hell out of my house.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: Your house? Who wants your house? Or your bullshit rules. Joe holds his ground though he wants to whack Patrick. Pa walks out the front door. Seamus still sits at the table eating pastries. Joe walks out of the living room. Margaret, with tears beginning to form in her eyes, looks at Seamus. Seamus sh his shoulders, takes a bite of his pastry, and stands up. puts his arms out to take Molly from her arms.

dialogues.speaker: SEAMUS
dialogues.text: Mom. You know how after you send me to my room, you come into my bedroom and we talk? I think Dad needs you to talk to him. Margaret hands Molly to Seamus and kisses him on the fore She enters the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe sits in his lounge chair drinking a beer and looks ou at the sun setting. Margaret pulls up a chair next to him

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Honey, I know what you're going to say. And my decision about the scholarship is final. Margaret stares at the sunset.

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: You know, when Father Murphy married us...

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Don't start with this crap. Margaret stops.

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: Father Murphy said...

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Father Murphy was an idiot. Margaret grabs the beer right out of Joe's hand. She thro it against the fence.

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: I have got something to say and you will not interrupt me until I am finished. Joe shrugs but realizes this isn't the time to fight her.

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: We agreed on a partnership. And our partnership has been for you to provide for the family while I raise the family. But somewhere along the line, this partnership has gotten out of whack. You come home, the house is clean, your food is hot, and your kids are behaved. You then bark orders at these children like a drill sergeant.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Cause they need discipline.

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: I am not finished. Trust me, these kids are disciplined. You think I run this house without discipline? Joseph, the older ones, they need more guidance than sterness. We've done our work with them, they now need to feel they can bounce things  off us.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: That's a bunch of crap. You think I bounced things off my dad? Hell no.

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: You hated your dad growing up.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Yeah, he was an asshole, but I respected him. And looking back, he did a great job.

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: But looking back is too late. It would be nice for Patrick to feel close enough to you so that he could tell you his dreams, tell you that even though he doesn't want to grow up to be you, that you are still his hero.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: That's bullshit.

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: Everything is not bullshit. I will not allow you to take away the chance for Patrick to pursue his dream. The rabbi is being generous and you think it reflects poorly on you.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: That's not...

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: Yes it is. You can't afford to put your children through college, so you've decided that college is bad. You know what, I agree college is a waste of time for most kids. But not Patrick. He wasted his first few years of high school, but the last two years he has worked his butt off and he generally loves to learn. That's what college is all about.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: How do you know what college is about?

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: Just because I didn't go doesn't mean I didn't think about it. But I fell in love, had babies, and haven't regretted one thing about the last nineteen years. Until now! You will not squash your children's dreams because they aren't your dreams.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: It's not about dreams, it's about what's right. If Patrick really wanted  college, he could have gotten better grades and earned a scholarship.

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: He didn't take school seriously. Why? Cause he thought it was a waste of time because he would work for the city whether he got A's or C's. But one day he woke up and decided that not doing his best was not the O'Malley way. And he learned that from his father. And he's got nothing but A's that day forward. And he will do the same in college. From a scholarship that he accepts from Rabbi Jacobsen, or so help me God, Joe, the only thing colder than your food when you get home will be your bed. Margaret stands up and walks back into the house. Joe is alone looking at a sun that has set in the sky.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pete sits on the floor alone playing the board game "All Star Baseball". He's busy spinning when Seamus enters.

dialogues.speaker: SEAMUS
dialogues.text: You can't play that game alone.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: You wanna play?

dialogues.speaker: SEAMUS
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: So I gotta play alone. I'm crushing you.

dialogues.speaker: SEAMUS
dialogues.text: How can you be crushing me?

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: I picked one team for me and one team for you. Seamus grabs the circular cards and looks at the teams.

dialogues.speaker: SEAMUS
dialogues.text: You've got Babe Ruth, Lou Gerhig, and Reggie Jackson. I've got nobody.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: I gave you Harmon Killebrew. And Reggie strikes out all the time anyway.

dialogues.speaker: SEAMUS
dialogues.text: These teams are unfair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then we can redraft. Seamus grabs his bat and glove.

dialogues.speaker: SEAMUS
dialogues.text: Maybe later.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: How long do you think Dad will ground me?

dialogues.speaker: SEAMUS
dialogues.text: Who knows. Today's only the first day. Definitely longer than one day. Seamus walks out of the bedroom and down the stairs. Kati is dancing in the living room. Seamus walks out the front door. Danny is standing at the door. He's sweaty and his White Sox hat is cockeyed.

dialogues.speaker: SEAMUS
dialogues.text: Hey. How you doing?

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Good thanks. Is Pete home?

dialogues.speaker: SEAMUS
dialogues.text: Yep. Upstairs. First room on the right. Take it easy. Danny enters the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pete spins. The spinner lands on nine, which indicates a strikeout. Pete laughs. Pete talks as if he's announcing the game.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: Another strikeout for Seamus's team. Pete's team, trying to be the first team ever in the hist of baseball to go undefeated, comes to bat with a thirtee run lead. (other announcer voice) Jack, they're not only undefeated, but they've ten run ruled every team they've played. (back to original announcer voice) Good point, Charlie. Danny enters the bedroom. Pete looks at him. He runs to t door, looks out in the hallway, pushes Danny inside the r and shuts the door.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: What are you doing here?

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: We've got to complete the decathlon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We can't. You gotta get outta here.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: We have to. I know I can do it.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: I'm grounded forever because of you. If my dad saw me with you, I'd be grounded to infinity.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: I'd be grounded to infinity if my parents knew I was here. They think I'm napping.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: I can't.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: I might not have another chance for awhile. I heard my mom talking to the doctor this morning. I think they're going to put me back in the hospital.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: Listen. I'm not going to disobey my dad again.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: You told me about risk/reward. The risk is worth it.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: No it's not.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Yes it is. I gotta be able to tell my parents I'm going to heaven. They need to know I'm happy in paradise.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: You wanna know the truth? Danny nods.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: You can't go to heaven. It's out of bounds, off limits, to Jews. There's nothing you can do. Danny shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: But you said.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: I was wrong. The only thing that I did was put myself on the road to hell with you. Danny screams.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, you said if I finish the decathlon, I'm going to heaven. Pete grabs Danny.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: You gotta go home. You're going to get me into trouble, and then I'm going to hell for sure. Danny opens the door and leaves the bedroom. Pete lays do on the floor.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: (announcer ) That was a brief rain delay. Pete's team comes to bat. Pete places a circular card into the spinner. He can't position the card into the spinner. He throws the game ac the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is overcast at the beach with the usual Chicago wind whipping off the waves of Lake Michigan. The beach is qui with just a few people running and biking. Danny puts on goggles. The waves are a little rougher today. He walks i the water. He dives in. Like a windmill, his arms splash and out of the water.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: One. Two. Three. Four. Danny continues to count his strokes. He breaks through t initial group of waves, but beyond the waves the water is choppy. The lifeguard in the tower looks out toward the l From his view, Danny is not visible. Danny's head barely bobs out of the water as he swims.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Fifty five. Fifty six. Fifty seven. Fifty eight. Fifty nine. Sixty. Danny looks up to see where the buoy is. He takes in some water. He thinks he sees the buoy but takes in more water He flips to his back and floats. He coughs up what water can. When he calms down, he turns his head slowly to chec for the buoy. He sees it not too far off in the distance. flips himself over, takes a little water, and begins to s toward the buoy. He counts his strokes.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Sixty one. Sixty two. Sixty three. Sixty four. Sixty five. Sixty six. Sixty seven. Sixty eight. Sixty nine. Seventy. Seventy one. Danny's hands grasp the buoy. He looks up at the buoy. Th water splashes off the buoy onto Danny. Danny flips over floats on his back. A big smile crosses his face.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Seventy one strokes. And a little more on the way back. I can do it. Danny floats on his back. He turns over and begins to swi toward the shore.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pete walks down the stairs. Joe passes the stairs on the to the front door. He looks at Pete but doesn't say anyth Joe walks out the front door. Pete heads toward the kitch Patrick runs past Pete and also heads out the front door. Mary takes a crying Molly out of the kitchen. Margaret cl off Molly's high chair.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: Hey Mom.

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: Hi honey.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: Where are Dad and going?

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: They have some business to take care of.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: Patrick's getting a job? Margaret bends down and fixes Pete's hair.

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: Always so busy worrying about everyone else's business. That's from my side of the family, you know?

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: Yeah. Dad tells me I get a lot from your side of the family.

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: That's right. Your sweetness, your humor, and definitely your nose.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: So you think Dad will end my grounding?

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: Are you sorry for disobeying your dad? And lying to your mom?

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: It wasn't really a lie. I told you I was going out to play.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you forgot to mention you were going to Lake Michigan and swimming with Danny. Pete nods.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: I'm sorry. It's just... it was a quest... and on a quest you have to take risks.

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: Lying to your mother is not a risk. It's wrong.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: I know. Can you talk to Dad and put a good word in for me? Margaret nods. Pete slowly heads out of the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: How did your quest end up?

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: Not good. I had to give it up.

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: You know, the way you went about your quest was wrong, sneaking to the beach and such, but the quest itself, it was good.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: But Dad said...

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: Sometimes, even dad's are wrong.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: Easy for you to say. He can't ground you.

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: Don't give up your quest.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: How do you know the quest is good?

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: I have faith. Pete nods and walks out of the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rabbi Jacobsen sits at his desk. He is hurriedly shufflin papers when he hears a knock at his door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on in. Joe and Patrick enter the rabbi's office. The rabbi stand up but is The rabbi not his usual effusive self.

dialogues.speaker: RABBI
dialogues.text: I'm glad you came to see me but when we spoke before, I thought I would have time to talk. My wife called and told me I am needed at the hospital.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Is everything OK? shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: RABBI
dialogues.text: Danny's not doing well.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: I am sorry.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: I'm sorry.

dialogues.speaker: RABBI
dialogues.text: I assume you want to talk about the scholarship? Patrick nods.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: It seems. I think. It's an opportunity for my son.

dialogues.speaker: RABBI
dialogues.text: It will open doors for Patrick that would be closed in today's society without a degree.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: I just can't... Patrick interrupts. The rabbi

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: We know it will and if the offer is still there, I would love a chance at it. grabs his briefcase.

dialogues.speaker: RABBI
dialogues.text: Patrick, the scholarship is yours. You will make us all proud.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: Thanks. Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: You better get going. We better get  going. I hope everything gets better with Danny.

dialogues.speaker: RABBI
dialogues.text: Thank you. The rabbi shows Joe and Patrick the door. The three exit office and then the synagogue. They talk for a few more seconds and then part ways.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe and Patrick listen to the White Sox game on the radio

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Luckily, the Cubs stink, or else a lot of White Sox fans would be flocking north.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: Never. There will be peace in Ireland before a Sox fan becomes a Cub fan. Joe laughs.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: You're probably right. And that's the way it should be. They listen to the game. A White Sox batter strikes out w the bases loaded.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: But they sure do test our loyalty.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: I'm gonna work my ass off, Dad. I'm not going to be some pot smoking, sleep 'till noon college slacker. I'm gonna do it right. Joe nods.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: I know. The two sit in silence as they drive home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pete is sitting on his bed tossing a tennis ball to himse Joe walks in.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Pedro.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: Hey Dad. Joe motions for the ball. Pete tosses it to him. Joe thr it back.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Seamus said there's a big game over at Holy Cross and they could probably use another player.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: So can I go?

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Yep. Pete jumps up from the bed.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: Sorry Dad. I won't disobey you again. Joe puts out his hand and Pete shakes it.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: I saw Rabbi Jacobsen last night. I guess Danny's back in the hospital.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: Yeah, Danny thought they might put him back in there. I hope he's doing all right.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: It's tough. What he's got. It's tough on a kid. And the family.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: I'll pray for him.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: That would be nice.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: I'll see you later Dad. Pete walks out of the room.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Pete? Pete pops his head back in.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: The rabbi also told me to tell you that Danny completed the decathlon. Seventy-one strokes there, eighty- six back. Pete's face lights up with a smile.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: No way? Joe nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I do it in fifty-five strokes.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: That's good.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: Yeah, but for his age and size, seventy-one strokes is great. He finished the decathlon! Pete walks out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pete rides his bike down the street toward the park. Holy Cross Church is attached to Holy Cross Elementary which i attached to Holy Cross Field, where the baseball field is located. Pete rides by the church and looks up at the big cross at the top of church. He rides toward the field and sees some of the boys playing catch while others sit on t bench and eat sandwiches. Seamus screams to Pete.

dialogues.speaker: SEAMUS
dialogues.text: Hurry up! Pete waves to the guys. He gets to the field and hops off his bike. He walks over to the bench where some guys are eating lun The corners of Jimmy Burns's lips are covered with jelly.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: Pete, you missed the first game. Your brother's team won again. Are you going to start playing with us again.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: Yep.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: The quest over? Pete nods. Kevin Muldoon pulls out a ham sandwich on whea

dialogues.speaker: KEVIN
dialogues.text: (To Jimmy) Trade you my ham and cheese sandwich for your other peanut butter and jelly sandwich?

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: What's your ham sandwich on?

dialogues.speaker: KEVIN
dialogues.text: Wheat. Got extra mayo.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: I hate wheat. Tastes like a sandwich on communion bread. Gross. Pete ears perk up at the sound of communion. He looks up the cross hanging high above the church. He takes off in full sprint for his bike. He jumps on it and heads toward the church.

dialogues.speaker: SEAMUS
dialogues.text: Where you going?

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: To finish the quest! Pete doesn't look back. He rides to the church, jumps off his bike, and runs into the church. The church is empty. Pete runs to the altar and grabs the communion chalice. H takes one, looks at it, and puts it in his pocket. He the takes another one just in case something happens to the f He puts the second communion host in his other pocket. Fa Kelly enters the altar from the hallway attached to the a

dialogues.speaker: FATHER
dialogues.text: Mr. O'Malley? Stealing communion? Pete stops dead in his tracks. He slowly turns and faces Father Kelly.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: Father Kelly.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER
dialogues.text: What are you doing? Tell me you're not hungry? Pete laughs.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: No Father, I'm not hungry. I hear this stuff isn't good anyway.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER
dialogues.text: I wish we'd change bread distributors, but that's neither here nor there. What are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: I've got a friend who really needs a piece of Jesus. Father Kelly looks perplexed.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: Ya see, he's really sick and in the hospital.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER
dialogues.text: We have people that give communion to the sick in the hospital.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: But they can't give it to him.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's not Catholic and he's only six.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER
dialogues.text: Well, that poses a problem. Communion is for Christians who have earned the right to receive Jesus and are of age.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: He's earned the right. He passed the tests.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER
dialogues.text: What tests?

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: Tests we made up to see if he's worthy of Jesus. And he is Father Kelly, he's as worthy as any Catholic I know. And just because he's not old enough, well that's not fair, because he may not live long enough to be old enough, and if Jesus didn't want him to have a piece of him only because he wasn't old enough, well, that doesn't seem like anything that sounds like the Jesus I know. Father Kelly stands speechless.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER
dialogues.text: Go give your friend the host. May God bless him. And you.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: Thanks Father. You too. Pete runs out of the church and onto his bike. WE FOLLOW as he rides a few blocks to the hospital. He enters the hospital and goes to the front desk.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: Danny Jacobsen?

dialogues.speaker: NURSE
dialogues.text: Room 4104. Fourth floor. Pete runs to the elevator, jumps in, and gets off on the fourth floor. He looks at the sign that points rooms 100-115 is to the right. Pete turns the corner toward room 104. The hallway empty. Room 115 on the right. Room 114 on the left. And t rooms descend in order as you walk the hallway. The hallw turns into another hallway to the left. Pete turns the co and sees Rabbi Jacobsen in the hallway with many friends relatives. Pete walks closer and the sound of crying fill the hallway. Pete starts to run. Rabbi Jacobsen sees Pete Pete pushes through the crowd. The rabbi makes his way to Pete. Pete stops before the Rabbi, who's eyes are red and cheeks are tear stained.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rabbi? Rabbi? I need to see Danny. The rabbi starts to cry. He opens his arms for Pete.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: Rabbi! No! Rabbi! I need to see him. I've got his communion. Right here. Pete pulls out the communion from his pocket.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: See! Danny earned it! He passed the decathlon.

dialogues.speaker: RABBI
dialogues.text: Danny passed on. He's no longer in pain.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: No! No! He didn't get his medal! The rabbi hugs Pete. Pete starts to cry. Harder. And hard In the rabbi's arms. The rabbi holds Pete tight. Pete bre away and runs into the room. Nurses attend to the equipme in the room. Danny lays on the bed with a sheet over his body. The rab comes into the room.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: I promised Danny, rabbi. I promised him.

dialogues.speaker: RABBI
dialogues.text: He told me.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: The prize for finishing the decathlon was a piece of Jesus. So he could go to heaven.

dialogues.speaker: RABBI
dialogues.text: He told me. He wanted to thank you. He told me that he'll see you in heaven some day.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: But he can't go without eating this. Rabbi! He can't go! Pete moves toward the bed. A nurse blocks him. The rabbi gently grabs Pete. Pete starts to cry. The rabbi carries Pete out of the room. The rabbi whispers in Pete's ears.

dialogues.speaker: RABBI
dialogues.text: God will let him into heaven, Pete. Danny has a good soul, and God will let him into heaven. The rabbi holds Pete in his arms outside of the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pete takes a stick and cleans out the dirt in his cleats while he sits on the bench.

dialogues.speaker: COACH
dialogues.text: All right, guys, we need baserunners. Three runs to tie, four to win. Let's go get ‘em. The players scream. Jimmy Burns pulls his hat backwards.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: Rally cap! Rally cap! The players turn their caps inside out and backwards. In stands behind the players, the fans, mainly parents, chee Joe sits with Margaret.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Last chance. I can't believe their not beating this team. Rabbi Jacobsen and his wife spot Joe in the stands. They wave to him and climb the stands. Joe and Margaret move d to make room for the Jacobsens. Joe shakes the rabbi's ha and Mrs. Jacobsen.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: We're down three runs. The rabbi nods.

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: We're very sorry for your loss.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. JACOBSEN
dialogues.text: Thank you. The flowers you sent were lovely. A player comes to the plate.

dialogues.speaker: RABBI
dialogues.text: I called your house and your daughter Mary said you'd be here.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Yep. Can't miss a game.

dialogues.speaker: RABBI
dialogues.text: Nope. A base hit. The fans cheer. Another player walks to the p

dialogues.speaker: RABBI
dialogues.text: How's Pete doing? Joe shrugs his shoulders.

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: He loved Danny. But he's a kid. They  move on better than we do.

dialogues.speaker: RABBI
dialogues.text: We can learn a lot from our children. The next batter pops out to second base. Another batter s to the plate. The rabbi field. The rabbi

dialogues.speaker: RABBI
dialogues.text: We sent the check for the University of Illinois. This is the receipt. hands Joe the receipt. The batter singles to left pulls out another document.

dialogues.speaker: RABBI
dialogues.text: And this is the legal document that explains our legal responsibility. Thirty pages to pretty much say we pay room, board, and tuition as long Patrick maintains a three point oh grade point average. Joe accepts the document and shakes the rabbi's hand. The batter grounds out. Two out. Another batter walks to the plate. Pete puts on a helmet and stands on deck. Ball four!

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Patrick will meet every requirement. This I know.

dialogues.speaker: RABBI
dialogues.text: Me too.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Thank you. Are you sure you don't want to do this in front of cameras?

dialogues.speaker: RABBI
dialogues.text: You didn't rush my burning house so you could get your picture on the front page.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: I looked around for the cameraman. I couldn't find him.

dialogues.speaker: RABBI
dialogues.text: A selfless act deserves a selfless act in return.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: RABBI
dialogues.text: Thank you. The batter walks to first base as the other base runners advance one base. Bases loaded. Down three runs. outs. Last inning. Pete pops the weight off of his bat an heads toward the plate. He looks into the stands and sees the Jacobsens sitting with his parents. He smiles. Befor steps to the plate, Pete closes his eyes. He opens his ey and steps to the plate. The pitcher winds up and throws t ball. Pete swings with all of his might and connects. The runners are off with the crack of the bat. The ball sails the air and toward center field. Deep center field. The c stands as Pete puts his head down and runs toward first b The center fielder speeds after the sailing ball. Pete ro first base and looks up. The center fielder dives as the ball looks like it is out of his reach. The ball hits the outer web of his glove and stays there miraculously like snowcone. Out! The center fielder caught the ball and the visiting crowd erupts. Pete falls between first and secon base and the home crowd lets out an audible groan. The visiting team runs out to center field to congratulat the center fielder, who stands, shows the ball, and smile wildly as his teammates tackle him. Jimmy Burns walks ove to Pete and helps him up. Joe watches wide eyed from the stands a Margaret covers h face in disbelief. The rabbi pats Joe on the back. Pete w back to the bench as his teammates and coaches console hi Pete looks up into the stands quietly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pete walks out to the stands where his parents and the Jacobsens wait for him. Margaret wants to hug him but kno that a hug from Mom in public is not what he wants. He lo to her wide eyed and she smiles.

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: You gave it your best shot.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: Yep. Joe pats him on the back.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: You gave that ball a ride, son. I've never seen you hit a ball so well. Pete nods. Rabbi Jacobsen puts his hand out. Pete shakes

dialogues.speaker: RABBI
dialogues.text: Nice try, Pete. Nice try.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: Thanks Rabbi. Hi, Mrs. Jacobsen. Mrs. Jacobsen smiles and hugs Pete. Pete looks at his mom and she gives him the OK sign. Pete hugs Mrs. Jacobsen.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. JACOBSEN
dialogues.text: I baked you some of that rugala you liked so much. It's in the car. Pete smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll come with you to get it. I'd love to know your recipe. Margaret and Mrs. Jacobsen walk toward the parking lot. Another parent walks over to talk to Joe. Pete stands alo with the rabbi.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: How's everything going?

dialogues.speaker: RABBI
dialogues.text: Well. And with you?

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: I really thought I hit that one over his head for a grand slam.

dialogues.speaker: RABBI
dialogues.text: You will.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: You know how you said Danny was in heaven? The rabbi nods.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: He's not. The comment staggers the rabbi. Joe looks over.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: I prayed to Danny before I hit that ball. I prayed to him in heaven to help me hit a grandslam. The rabbi nods.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: He's not in heaven to answer my prayers, rabbi. I thought you should know.

dialogues.speaker: RABBI
dialogues.text: Peter, our prayers are not answered in our time, but in God's time.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: No. Rabbi. Danny said he would answer my prayers to let me know he was in heaven. I gave him two weeks till I prayed. He didn't answer my prayer. The rabbi is visibly hurt. Joe walks over.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Everything OK? The rabbi nods.

dialogues.speaker: RABBI
dialogues.text: Yes. I better get going. I have temple in a few hours. It was nice to see you. The rabbi turns and walks toward the parking lot. Joe loo at Pete. Pete turns and walks toward the bench where some of the players are still sitting. Joe watches the rabbi walk to parking lot.

dialogues.speaker: EXT, O'MALLEY BACKYARD
dialogues.text: Pete stands in the backyard throwing the ball to the dog. the background, in the kitchen, Joe hands Patrick the leg document stating the rules of the scholarship. Patrick hu his dad. Joe pats Patrick on the back. He lets go and Pat bear hugs Margaret. The dog returns the ball and drops it Pete's feet. He bends down to pick up the ball and throws again. The dog chases after the ball. Joe walks outside. Pete turns.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: Hey Dad. The dog returns the ball. Pete picks it up.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Let's see your arm. Pete tosses the ball. The dog chases after it. Joe catche it.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Nice throw. Joe looks at the rubber ball.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: What'd you say to Rabbi Jacobsen?

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: Not much. Joe tosses the ball. Pete catches it.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: You must have said something.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: I told him Danny wasn't in heaven. Pete throws Joe the ball.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: How do you know?

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: I prayed to Danny to let me hit a grandslam. I didn't.  Joe hands the dog the ball and walks closer to Pete. He sits down in the lounge chair and motions for Pete to sit down next to him.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Your brother Patrick is going to college.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: I know. He's so excited.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: I never went to college.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: Why not?

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Cause I couldn't afford it. And I got a good job. And then I started a family. And I had to take care of my family

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: That sounds good.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: It is good. And you know what I've learned?

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: Huh? The dog drops the ball at Joe's feet. Joe picks it up and tosses it Pete nods. softly in the air to Pete.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: I've learned that you take care of family. No matter what your differences are. You're family. And taking care of them is a dad's job. He tosses the ball and the dog chases it.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: You know Jesus is Jewish?

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: Yep.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: And you know God is Jesus' father?

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: Uh-huh.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: So God's probably Jewish too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What I'm getting at, and I'm just thinking aloud, but if God is any kind of father, do you think he would turn his back on his own people, the Jewish people, and not let them back into his house? Pete shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Of course he wouldn't. Just like I wouldn't turn my back on you or any of your brothers or sisters. Dads take care of their family.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: So what are you saying? Joe laughs.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: I'm saying, maybe Danny is in heaven. Even though he's Jewish. I'm saying maybe when they say the kingdom of heaven can only be reached through Jesus, maybe what they really mean is heaven can be reached through being a good person just like Jesus. An Eskimo at the North Pole, who never heard of Jesus, who's been a good person all his life, shouldn't he be allowed into heaven?

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: Yes. But...

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: But what?

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: But then there's no need for me to listen to the nuns at school anymore. Joe laughs.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: You're not going to get out of Catholic school that easily. You still have to listen to them.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: But they're wrong.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: They're not wrong. They're just teaching one way to get to heaven.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: Sister Leonora Mary says there is only one way.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Well then, you and I will have to keep a secret from Sister Leonora Mary. Pete laughs. The dogs brings back the ball and drops it a Pete's feet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe and Pete enter the synagogue. Rabbi Jacobsen stands a the pulpit and he is speaking to a quarter full audience. Pete grabs a yarmukle and puts it on his head. He looks a his dad to do the same thing. His dad, reluctantly, puts on a yarmukle. The two take a seat in the back row. The rabbi finishes speaking and the people disperse. Pete waits for them all to pass the last row when he stands up. Rabbi Jacobsen has his back to Pet as he gives instructions to his assistant. Pete heads tow the altar as Joe stays in the pew.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: Rabbi Jacobsen. The rabbi turns. He smiles at Pete. He notices Joe in the back and waves to him. Joe gestures back.

dialogues.speaker: RABBI
dialogues.text: You cleaned up well from your game. What can I do for you?

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: Do you have a moment to talk?

dialogues.speaker: RABBI
dialogues.text: Sure.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: You know how I had my quest to get a Jewish person to heaven? The rabbi nods.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: Did you realize that my quest is just like your quest as a rabbi, it's just that I called mine a quest and you call yours a job.

dialogues.speaker: RABBI
dialogues.text: I didn't realize that but it seems to be true.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: Well, my quest ended with Danny. The rabbi nods.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: But your quest never ends cause it's your job.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think you're right.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: Well I learned something on my quest that might help you on your quest.

dialogues.speaker: RABBI
dialogues.text: What did you learn?

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: I learned that just saying you believe or just praying to Jesus isn't how you get to heaven.

dialogues.speaker: RABBI
dialogues.text: No?

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: Nope. Jesus is only a symbol, like a letter or a number. You could really use anyone's name just so long that the person's name symbolized being good.

dialogues.speaker: RABBI
dialogues.text: That is interesting.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: Yeah. I thought you might think so. My dad says I better stick to praying and acting like Jesus because the nuns wouldn't understand as well as you and him do. The rabbi looks up and smiles at Joe. Joe waves back.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: But, my dad and I think if the Jewish people don't want to copy the Christians by praying to Jesus, you guys can make up your own name to pray to.

dialogues.speaker: RABBI
dialogues.text: Do you have a suggestion for a name that I can bring to my congregation?

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: Danny. The rabbi's eyes fill with tears and he puts his arms out for Pete. Pete hugs him. And the rabbi squeezes tight. Pete lets go

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: I thought that might help you in your job. On your quest.

dialogues.speaker: RABBI
dialogues.text: Thank you. It will.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll see you later. Pete turns and walks toward his dad, who stands at the ba of the temple. Pete turns back to the rabbi.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: I almost forgot to tell you the most important thing.

dialogues.speaker: RABBI
dialogues.text: What's that?

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: That Danny is in heaven.

dialogues.speaker: RABBI
dialogues.text: How do you know?

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: Faith. Pete smiles and turns around. He walks to his dad and Pet and his dad walk out of the temple together.
